replies.msg:
are u Japanese ? welcome
because ur username is a Japanese name so I think u are.

i was not born here, i do not look like a chinese,
my cantonese is not good as yours, but i went to local school like you.
i even reg'd in JUPAS.
every day because of the protest i scroll on LIHKG

i cry because hk is my home and when i see
young people fighting for our rights
old people protecting the frontlines
firefighter and ambulance officers taking stand with us
against the nonsense government and police

my heart feels so damn heavy
i cannot protest as actively as i did in 2014
because now my job ethically requires me not to be so explicit
so i become more active online
and every day... my cantonese is getting better
so to answer your question, i was not born here,
i dont look like a chinese,
but im sure as hell am 100% HKer
香港人
反抗!

Thank you for supporting us bro!

We should not determine whether you are a Hong konger or not from your outlook. If you support the core values of Hong Kong such as freedom and democracy, you are one of us!

I really appreciate that you keep following the information on LIHKG even it is hard for you to read! Let’s chat and discuss more on the world forum!

replies.msg:
you are HK people.
you are one of us.
Stand with us, then you are HKers!
Welcome all of you

I share the same enthusiasm with all Lindon'ers (users active on LIHKG forum) to welcome everybody interested in the LIHKG forum and the current HK protests.

It is our duty to make you all feel at home. Please ask any questions here, either under this thread or by making a new one. You may hear different opinions, sometimes conflicting, from users of LIHKG as it has always been for this forum.

Please do not feel uncomfortable just because you do not speak Chinese or look like a Chinese when a lot of us consider ourselves Hongkongers rather than Chinese. The word "core values" had been used a lot up to the emergence of an "identity crisis" immediately preceding this protest. Just to show you that what actually bond us together are values and self perception, not language and ethnicity.

All our slogans can be linked to the aspirations of democracy and the desire for freedom..... Oops, sorry for the TLDR...
